item.title: I can help with maths
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“Sprite30, post:32, topic:1848”]i hav a question for sum1: wats the domain and range of

f(x) = -2x + 1

any1??[/quote]

Well the domain of a function is the set of all real numbers that can be applied for x that ensure that f(x) results in a real value; the key points too look out for in basic problems like this are possible negative square roots and divisions by zero. As this problem has neither square roots nor division, you’re safe to say that the domain is the set of all real numbers.

The range of a function is the set of all real numbers that f(x) can result with. As your function is a linear equation, the range is also the set of all real numbers. The main thing you need to look out for here is powers of multiples of 2 (^2, ^4, etc) since they result in only positive values.

Read full topic

item.title: I can help with maths
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

[quote=“BobDole81, post:25, topic:1848”]Iamadam: Suppose your first value (7 - 2sqrt2) is x and your second value (sqrt2 - 2) is y, just for simplicity.

To find two values in between these two values you basically need to find the difference between the end values and divide by 3…it’s similar finding the midvalue the between 2 values, but this time as there are 3 ‘spaces’ between numbers (between x and m, between m and p, and between p and y) instead of two when averaging (theres only 1 value in between the end values to find), you just divide by 3 instead…hope that makes any sense, but if not, just refer to my first sentence :D…

So once you have that value (the difference of the two values divided by 3), you figure out that x is the higher value and y is the lower, so you start at x and subtract this value from x to figure out m and you add it to y to figure out p.[/quote]

Thats what I did lol, but i still never get the right answer…which is kinda annoying.
I had
m - 7 - (2sqrt2), = p -m = (sqrt2)- 2 - p
Then solved the first one for p i think, and substituted that into the second equation. But i end up with the wrong answer somehow. Well, thanks for the help anyway

Read full topic

item.title: I can help with maths
item.dc:creator: @afi afi
item.description:
@afi wrote:

Use these figures when referenced.

1: For Figure 1, which point corresponds with the ordered pair (1,-1)?
F

G

B

2: For Figure 1, what are the (x,y) coordinates of A?
(-3, 2)

(-4, -2)

(-4, 2)

3: For Figure 1, which letter corresponds to the ordered pair (4, -3)?
J
I
H

4: For Figure 1, what are the (x,y) coordinates of E?
(-1,-4)
(1, 4)
(-1, 4)

5: For Figure 1, which letter corresponds to the origin?
G
F
H

6: For Figure 1, what are the coordinates of C?
(-4, -2)
(4, -5)
(-4, -5)

7: For this equation; y = 2x - 3;
If x = -3, then y = _____.
-9
-7
9

8: For this equation; y = 2x - 3;
If x = 4, then y = _____.
11
3
5

9: Which of the following ordered pairs is NOT a solution of the equation: x + 2y = 4?
(-6, 1)
(2, 1)
(6, -1)

10: Which of the following ordered pairs is a solution of the equation: 2x - 3y = 12?
(0, 4)
(8, 4/3)
(-3, -5)

11: Which of the following is not a linear equation?
x2 + y2 = 25
y = -3x
3x + 4y = 12

12: Which of the following is the linear equation drawn in Figure 2?
2x + 3y = 12
y = 2x - 3
y = 2x - 2

13: Which of the following ordered pairs is NOT on the line in Figure 2?
(0, -2)
(1, -4)
(2, 2)

14: Which of the following equations is the linear equation drawn in Figure 3?
y = 2x + 1
2x + y = -1
y = -(1/2)x + 1

15: Which of the following ordered pairs is on the line in Figure 3?
(-2, 2)
(-1, 1)
(1, 0)

16: Which of the following equations is the linear equation drawn in Figure 4?
y = -2x + 4
y = -2x
2x - y = -1

17: Does the line graphed in Figure 3 pass through the origin?
maybe
yes
no

18: Does the line graphed in Figure 4 pass through the origin?
maybe
yes
no

19: Evaluate this function if x = 3:
f(x) = 2x + 4
7
9
10

20: For the evaluation above, what are the ordered pairs?
(10, 9)
(3, 10)
(3, 9)

Read full topic

item.title: I can help with maths
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Iamadam: Suppose your first value (7 - 2sqrt2) is x and your second value (sqrt2 - 2) is y, just for simplicity.

To find two values in between these two values you basically need to find the difference between the end values and divide by 3…it’s similar finding the midvalue the between 2 values, but this time as there are 3 ‘spaces’ between numbers (between x and m, between m and p, and between p and y) instead of two when averaging (theres only 1 value in between the end values to find), you just divide by 3 instead…hope that makes any sense, but if not, just refer to my first sentence :D…

So once you have that value (the difference of the two values divided by 3), you figure out that x is the higher value and y is the lower, so you start at x and subtract this value from x to figure out m and you add it to y to figure out p.

Read full topic

item.title: I can help with maths
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Assuming it is suppose to be:

((cos(t) * cot(t)) - (sin(t) * tan(t)) * sin(t) * cos(t)
----------------------------------------------------------
                    (cos(t) - sin(t))

For the first part of the first line:
((cos(t) * cot(t)) = (cos(t) * cos(t)/sin(t)) = (cos^2(t) / sin(t))
since cot(t) = cos(t)/sin(t)

For the second part of the first line:
(sin(t) * tan(t)) = (sin(t) * sin(t)/cos(t)) = (sin^2(t) / cos(t))
since tan(t) = sin(t)/cos(t)

Now we have:

((cos^2(t) / sin(t)) - (sin^2(t) / cos(t))) * sin(t) * cos(t)
----------------------------------------------------------
                    (cos(t) - sin(t))

Since there is a sin(t) and cos(t) outside of this block, they can be multiplied in individually to result in:

(cos^3(t) - (sin^3(t))
----------------------
  (cos(t) - sin(t))

Looking at cos^3(t) - (sin^3(t) as a difference of two cubes, we get:

(cos(t) - sin(t))(cos^2(t) + cos(t)sin(t) + sin^2(t))
-----------------------------------------------------
                  (cos(t) - sin(t))

After which the (cos(t) - sin(t))'s cancel out. Next, we can use a pythagorean identity to work it down:

cos^2(t) + cos(t)sin(t) + sin^2(t)
(cos^2(t) + sin^2(t)) + cos(t)sin(t)
1 + cos(t)sin(t)

And 1 + cos(t)sin(t) is as far as I can get right now I can't think of whether I can simplify it any further right now, but I think it's right...went through it once quickly.

Read full topic
